newsitem.title: INDIA: Hopes for India budget approval cheer business.
newsitem.headline: Hopes for India budget approval cheer business.

text.p: Indian businessmen said on Sunday they welcomed news the much-praised 1997/98 budget could be passed at a special parliamentary session later this month, despite the fall of the pro-reform United Front government.

Technically, the 1997/98 (April-March) budget, handed down in February, is a piece of legislation held over from the defunct United Front government of Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda, which lost a confidence vote in parliament on Friday.

The budget must still be agreed by parliament. Its approval is widely seen as a test of politicians' commitment to continuing economic reforms, despite underlying philosophical differences, analysts said on Sunday.
"The consensus on the budget is a positive signal and will help boost stock market sentiments," Subroto Ray, head of research at DBS Capital Trust Securities, told Reuters.
But the United Front's tax-slashing measures and steps to boost investment, welcomed by businessmen as spurring industry, have won favour with India's other political parties as well.

"The readiness shown by different political parties to discuss the Finance Bill is a silver lining in the prevailing precipitative politics," said A.S. Kasliwal, chief of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry.
Wracked by internal dissent, neither the United Front nor its Congress foe are ready for polls. Each is paralysed by backroom wrangling.
Standing by is the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which has the most to gain from new polls.
None of the parties want to risk public anger by blocking the budget.
Business groups fear the uncertainty and imminent elections will jolt the economy and send negative signals to foreign investors, who have been wooed through market-friendly policies.
"There is a lack of comfort amongst business because of lack of stability in the governance of the country," said Shekhar Datta, president of the Confederation of Indian Industry.

Parliament Speaker P.A. Sangma met President Shankar Dayal Sharma on Saturday to plead for a special budget session. Sangma's spokesman said later that Sharma had agreed to help move the budget for consideration in parliament during April 21 to 23.
"I welcome the decision of all political parties to pass the budget at a special session of the Lok Sabha," said H.L. Somany, president of the Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowd said before being defeated in the trust vote on Friday that parliament would seek approval of the budget on April 21.
Finance Minister P. Chidambaram's budget has been hailed by industry for its plans to cut corporate taxes, lower income tax and reduce import tariffs.
"The Appropriation Bill and The Finance Bill will be placed for approval of parliament," said a finance ministry official, who asked not to be identified.

The Appropriation Bill, already examined by a parliamentary panel, lists the demands for grants or the spending proposals of the various ministries. The Finance Bill gives effect to the tax and tariff proposals outlined in the 1997/98 budget.
"The parties can move amendments if they wish to do so and then the bill can be voted (on)," the official said.
The government so far has been empowered by a vote-on-account, or a bill authorising spending for 1996/97 programmes, until mid-May.
If the Finance Bill is not passed by then, the old tax and tariff rates set by government in its 1996/97 budget will continue, the finance ministry official said.
Business leaders feared that the prospect of a fresh election and a new government will hit key policy decisions in infrastructure and delay domestic and foreign investment.
"Investors will wait and watch before making any commitment," a chief dealer at a foreign securities firm said.
